Award.AwardTitle: Postdoctoral Fellow with an Interdisciplinary Approach to Law and Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
To facilitate greater intellectual collaboration among the existing set of socio-legal scholars at Tulane University, this project will support a postdoctoral fellow in law and society whose research takes an interdisciplinary approach to legal studies. The postdoctoral fellow would be embedded within the research and scholarly community at Tulane University. The postdoctoral fellow will receive mentoring from senior faculty, participate in an interdisciplinary community, and mentor undergraduate student research assistants.

This project will nurture a scholar in legal studies by fostering close research, mentoring, and networking interactions. Interdisciplinary scholarship in law and society takes place within several disciplines, including law, sociology, political science, psychology, and anthropology. Thus, this project will facilitate the intellectual development of the law and society community at Tulane University by expanding the university's capacity, with a goal of drawing scholars, policy makers, and the legal community to its base in New Orleans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project were to hire a postdoctoral fellow in law and society, support his or her research in the field of law and society with an intersectional approach, and have him or her contribute to the law and society community at Tulane. 

We hired Bonnie Lucero, a promising early career scholar in September 2017. She was in residence as a postdoctoral fellow for one year, leaving in September 2018 to take a position as Director of the Center for Latino Studies at the University of Houston-Downtown despite being offered a second year with us. Professor Lucero was incredibly productive during her time here, making significant progress on publications, undertaking new research, mentoring an undergraduate student, taking on new teaching roles, presenting at conferences, and being a vibrant member of the intellectual community at Tulane. 

 

The fellowship enabled Professor Lucero to complete her first two monographs and make substantial progress on a third monograph. In the realm of teaching, she was able to fulfill a long-term goal of teaching incarcerated people, an experience that renewed her enthusiasm and confidence in the classroom. Beyond these two tangible outcomes, participating in the scholarly community at Newcomb enabled her to develop a strong vision for how to approach the advancement of undergraduate women of color and acquire foundational skills she needs to realize that vision in her new professional role.

 

Specifically, Professor Lucero accomplished the following:

 

  • Finalized copyedits, page proofs, and index for her first monograph, Revolutionary Masculinity and Racial Inequality: Gendering War and Politics in Cuba, 1895-1902. To be released by the University of New Mexico Press in December 2018.
  • Submitted the final revised manuscript and completed copyediting of her second monograph, A Cuban City, Segregated: Race and Urbanization in the Nineteenth Century. To be released in March 2019.
  • Conducted preliminary research using Tulane University’s library stacks and digital subscriptions, and completed archival research in Spain and Cuba for her current project, tentatively titled Malthusian Practices: A History of Pregnancy, Abortion, and Infanticide in Cuba since Colonial Times.
  • Began revising an article titled “‘A Fatal Example for Slavery’: Race and Fertility Control Law in Colonial Cuba,” which she had originally submitted to the peer-reviewed scholarly journal Slavery & Abolition in June 2017, and for which she received readers’ reports in July 2017. She is planning to resubmit the revised article by December 2018.
  • Conducted archival research in Washington, D.C. at the National Archives and the National Library of Medicine, as well as identifying potential resources at the Smithsonian Institutes in January 2018 for her current project, Malthusian Practices
  • Conducted archival research with an undergraduate research assistant in Madrid, Spain at the Spanish National Archives in May 2018 for her current project, Malthusian Practices
  • Conducted archival research with an undergraduate research assistant in Havana, Cuba at the Cuban National Archives, Cuban National Library, Institute of History of Cuba, and University of Havana in June 2018 for her current project, Malthusian Practices
  • Provided two rounds of peer review for the New West Indian Review
  • Supervised undergraduate research assistant in compiling a data set on maternal and infant health indicators in the early twentieth century in Cuba. That data set will form part of the fourth chapter of her third book, Malthusian Practices.
  • Participated in team teaching Introduction to Women’s Studies at Louisiana Correctional Institute for Women with Dr. Kenney in Spring 2018
  • Participated in a women’s writing group
  • Attended events including talks by Catharine McKinnon, Kimberlé Crenshaw, Rebecca Solnit, and others; a dialogue between Alicia Garza and Elizabeth Alexander; a women’s political caucus event with Donna Brazile, and the Fridays at Newcomb lecture series.
  • Observed and learned about best practices for serving undergraduate women that she will be putting into practice in her new position as Director of the Center for Latino Studies at University of Houston-Downtown

Professor Lucero presented her work in numerous settings during the year:

  • Presented a portion of her findings from her first monograph in a paper titled, “Race, Gender, and Socially-Appropriate Education in US-Occupied Cuba,” at the American Historical Association Annual Conference in Washington, D.C. in January 2018
  • Presented a portion of her current project in a paper titled “To Protect the ‘Man of the Cradle’: Race and Fertility Control in Cuba’s Slave Society,” at an International Conference called “Intimate Politics: Fertility Control in a Global Historical Perspective,” at the University of Edinburgh in Edinburgh, Scotland in May 2018
  • Gave one guest lecture on the Cuban Revolution for a Latin American Studies course in October 2017, and led 2 class discussions on prostitution in Cuba for Dr. Mahoney’s Newcomb Scholars course in November 2017 and April 2018
  • Gave public talk on her current project, Malthusian Practices in February 2018 for Fridays at Newcomb series
